pros: Company works hard to provide mission based services to king county un and underinsured as well as Medicaid clients.
cons: EHR can be tricky to learn and makes documentation challenging

pros: flexible schedule, chill environment, reasonable workload
cons: management is not great, micromanage randomly and don't provide support when needed

job_title: IT Help Desk Technician in Tukwila, WA
pros: The pay is well above market
cons: Total Shitshow -lied about ability to develop, learn and grow here -Totally disconnected leadership -middle managers are barely competent at best, at worst they're dangerously incompetant -middle management routinely abandons employees and barely trains them -many employees refuse to learn the skills or processes required to their job -zero cooperation between departments -everybody is full game theory because you can't get fired here so coasting along and avoiding any changes or rocking boat

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Auburn, WA
pros: Free supervision for licensure is hard to beat and it is good supervision too. Coworkers are great and dedicated to the job they do while they are there.
cons: Case loads are high and loaded with high needs cases which can be stressful. There dose seem to be high turn over due to stressful conditions.

job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Seattle, WA
pros: Good team for support. Lots of learning opportunities.
cons: High caseloads and high turn over of staff

pros: I learned a lot about working with the disabled community, and the employees were pretty spectacular (with a few exceptions).
cons: Pay could be better, but a great place to stay long-term or as entry after college.

pros: Pros are few and far between, besides getting experience
cons: The compensation for mental health workers is incredibly below market rate. Caseloads are high and there are no worker protections. Company has a long history of unions busting

pros: Stable work and always busy
cons: Front line People of color has been pushed out at the corporate offices in operations

pros: Free supervision and supportive management
cons: Unhappy staff that made workplace negative

pros: Easy to get hired on. Coworkers are relatively nice and easy to work with.
cons: low pay. low staffed (solitary work environment), could use better benefits. property management is not trained in working with people with substance use disorders, mental health conditions, or crisis situations.

job_title: Child and Family Clinician in Bellevue, WA
pros: Supervision and medical benefits are free
cons: Pay is barely a living wage for single people

pros: Friendly work atmosphere and culture.
cons: If you're one that wants a fast paced environment, this may not be the place for you.

pros: If you're on the right team with supportive supervisors it's a dream! Lots of freedom to do a variety of modalities and see a variety of types of clients. It's interesting the the exec board is all therapists. Great internship site too. So much experience! Good place to start.
cons: Just about everything else. Huge case loads, so much paperwork, constant changes, the exec board says they want to hear from you then do the opposite of what you say would make work better. Way too low of pay, no real indication of when raises will happen. Very little possibility for growth/progression. They were supposed to have finished bargaining with our new union in November and haven't. They also did a lot of union busting when we were trying to unionize. Most recently they are putting all the pressure of the new medicaid funding system on clinicians. Clinician's are clinicians not in charge of budgeting deficits. I truly wanted to work there my whole career because I love the population but they make it literally impossible.

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Seattle, WA
pros: Structured environment, administrative support, ongoing education
cons: Disorganized, technology issues, low pay

review_title: They do the best they can
job_title: Licensed Mental Health Therapist in Burien, WA
pros:
Working with an incredible population as well as a team of esteemed professionals. 
Worked hard to step up diversity and diversity training. 
Paid holidays 
Great training/supervision for those that are looking for work out of school.
cons:
It's difficult for them to provide a competitive wage which leads to a lack of employees, which affects case loads and staff burn out.
I'm sure they are offering the best insurance they can and it's not that great.

review_title: awesome PTO nice co workers but pay is low
job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Bellevue, WA
pros: You get 4.5 hours of vacation days every paycheck and 4 hours of sick time per paycheck. You get paid every other Friday. There is a 3 percent raise every July. Health benefits are paid for by the company.
cons: The salary is really low and the company is going through a lot of changes and feels like you don’t get support from upper management and you have to scramble to get questions answered from a co worker that has been there long enough to answer your question.

pros: some control over schedule. some flexibility to WFH (may be changing as we phase out of covid). free supervision.
cons: limitations on how often you can see clients. focus on CBT and basically it erases anyone who does not have that therapeutic orientation. low pay. hard to accommodate flexible schedules.

pros: Good leave, average pay for the field
cons: Not many cons to speak of

review_title: Upper Management is a no go
job_title: Residential Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Flexible work schedule, opportunities to be independent
cons: No support from upper management, large case load, unrealistic expectations

pros: Supervision was very helpful and insightful
cons: Client availability was sparse at times

job_title: Child and Family Therapist in Tukwila, WA
pros:
Free Supervision
Lots of experience
Decent benefits
cons:
High caseload 
Low pay
Not enough training

pros: really great direction the company is heading in.
cons: still large caseloads but improving. wages need to be higher

job_title: Case Manager in Lake City, King, WA
pros: Great place to work, decent pay and benefits
cons: Virtually no other co-workers around.

job_title: PATH Case Manager in Tukwila, WA
pros: Work/Life balance is great. There's a lot of flexibility in your schedule. They reimburse mileage. Advancement is possible. Bi-yearly raises. End of year bonus. 401k matching.
cons: Low pay for the Seattle area. Raises are only 3%. Not much to say against the company.

pros: Team works closely with one another. Opportunities to form strong professional connections with clients.
cons: Things are prepared for Outpatient over Residential. It appears that we are thought of last when events or changes are made.

review_title: Excellent work environment, flexible and supportive of staff
pros: Team support, leaders in their field.
cons: Competitive pay in the field, but the field does not pay well.

job_title: Family Counseling Therapist, LMHCA in Seattle, WA
pros: Amazing team to work with
cons: Employees are disposable and low paid, as a result most are burned out and leave too early. Clients don't get good care due to this.

job_title: Mental Health Clinician/Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: You'll get great experience because you get thrown into every kind of situation with clients. There are some great people that work here, but that is not across the board and they don't promote staff based on actual qualifications. Seems like the new CEO has a good idea about things that need to change, but change is slow and there are a lot of corrupt people in high places. PTO is pretty good, about 3 weeks a year plus separate sick leave time.
cons: Low pay (basically minimum wage even with a MA), high caseloads, high expectations, little to no support for clinical staff, no supervision, extremely hard to accrue hours towards a clinical license, many higher ups in the agency are not licensed or qualified to provide supervision, and the new HSA and medical benefit plan leaves you paying for a lot of your coverage on your own. Also they don't reward creativity or suggestions by employees. It very much feels like those that are providing the direct services are treated as the lowest of the low. People in management positions are mostly promoted based on who likes you/who you're friends with, rather than qualifications and ability. I could go on and on, but after working here for years, I would not recommend working at this agency.

pros: It was a Great Opportunity
cons: there are No cons that i could think of

review_title: Rewarding experience but not worth the issues from management
job_title: Residential Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Flexible hours and decent pay
cons: Toxic work environment, no communication between depts, constantly understaffed, and the facilities lack the appropriate security measures to ensure the safety of their residents and employees

review_title: Residential programs tend to be pushed aside
job_title: Residential Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Flexible hours and decent pay
cons: toxic work environment, very little communication between departments, consistently understaffed, facilities lack appropriate security measures to ensure the safety of clients and staff

job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Bellevue, WA
pros: You get experience but you also get overwhelmed.
cons: Pay is low. Benefits are not that good.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Sammamish, WA
pros: Good team, diverse client base
cons: Poor pay, inadequate supervision for starting professionals

pros: Meaningful work with communities in need
cons: Medicaid funding adds bureaucratic complications

pros: Working with clients is genuinely rewarding and is now a unionized workplace.
cons: For the last four years, Sound has been rapidly in decline due to arrogant and tone deaf policy changes from the Executive Leadership Team that are largely driven by profit. The ELT violated several labor laws during their brazen attempt to stifle organizing and the CEO is grossly unprofessional by sending vaguely threatening emails that gaslight staff and push a false narrative about a divided organization. The sweeping changes Sound has implemented over the last few years to focus on turning a profit is truly a race to the bottom and at odds with being a positive community presence. The loss of numerous contracts with the city and county is very telling as is Sound's increasing poor reputation.

pros: Pay is competitive; CEO is amazing (but retiring) and most management;is excellent, as are most co-workers - health insurance still very affordable and overall benefits package is great.  Organization as a whole is generally supportive of innovative thinkers and new ideas.  They understand that we have families and lives outside of work and encourage healthy boundaries and self care.
cons: There are always a few personalities that clash -- sometimes some of the Masters level providers hire on and then act as if they are shocked that they are not making Microsoft type starting salaries; like maybe there is some big lie going around in all schools of Psychology and Social Work at all universities that says "Hey!  Be a therapist and get rich!", or "Social Work is where the real money is at!"  The pay is not what you would get at Boeing or Microsoft, but that should be fairly evident to a college graduate.

review_title: This place still can't  get it together....
pros: Good clinicians with good hearts, multiple locations, diverse program opportunities
cons: With the change in leadership two years ago we were told things would be better. Nothing has changed. It's more of the same and only getting worse. Client care is still awful, case loads are still dangerously high given the rate of complex-needs. Our reputation among hospitals and providers is awful and continuing to work against them simply because they're competition does nothing for our purpose and mission. We're all in this together but not participating is not helpful. Current CEO takes things way too personal. You're an adult with an executive title, act like it.

job_title: Administrative Division Staff in Seattle, WA
pros: The majority of staff are warm, caring, competent, and open-minded. Excellent benefits and competitive payscale for a non-profit. Organization makes a positive difference in the lives of many people.  They also place a high premium on workplace safety and on building strong relationships between staff and consumers, and do so well.
cons: Despite casual atmosphere and open-door management policy, the organizational politics can make life at SMH very uncomfortable.  Unspoken rules and interpersonal contracts abound, and there are a lot of mixed messages about how one is expected to fit into the culture.  Heaven help you if you try to question the Way Things Are Done!

review_title: Client of clinicians at seniors apt
pros: 2 clinicians on site here at the ERNESTINE ANDERSON PLACE APTS. to provide day to day support with obstacles of aging with issues.
cons:
Workers are burnt out, only do the bare minimum. Activities include games and the zoo. What is actually needed is organized bi-monthly grocery or food bank trips.
Med management, referrals to day centers for hot meals etc. 
Clients are entitled to much, but counselors are not proactive in helping clients live well,  Not once have they visited my apt to see how I am actually managing. Even as payees they just hand you your check and turn away. One lady in particular begs me for food because she's in a wheelchair and cannot get around, and her check is stolen by another client every month. That is ridiculous. Not sure they have any support or incentive to give a damn.

pros:
Office is dog friendly
Free parking in a few lots
Good neighborhood 
Health benefits were great, now they are so-so.
cons: Poor communication, lay-offs w/no explanation, mis-management of budget, low morale among employees, not much in the way of leadership or training opportunities, disorganized (i.e., clients waiting for 3 hours in lobby only to be told they won't be seen and to come back another day), employee concerns are handled poorly and not in a timely manner. The chief clinical officer makes the big decisions and does not have a clinical degree. The culture is that of fear and paranoia due to lack of communication, and the senior managers do not try to get to know employees. Upper management does not practice what they preach and the burnout rate is extremely high.

review_title: I'm proud to work for SMH
job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Seattle, WA
pros: SMH is WA's largest community mental health agency. Job security is great here. Our services are always in high demand. We help make our community a better place, offering a wide range of community mental health services to underserved and low income residents of King County, WA. I found the organization, leadership, salary, and benefits all to be highly satisfactory during the years I have worked here.
cons: As a large metro CMHC, SMH can be a stressful and challenging place to work, largely because of the types of clients we serve. Burnout is a risk many people face,  but I believe the management here takes both its employees and its clients' health and welfare seriously. You should be prepared to work hard, stay busy, and potentially encounter very challenging and severely mentally ill clients working here. The demands of this type of agency are not for everyone.

job_title: Substance Abuse Counselor in Tukwila, WA
pros: Co workers are great. Clients are great. You get 400 for training money per year. You get reimbursed for your licenses. You get 1,000 each year put in your HSA account.
cons: You have mental health clients with no SUD issues on your case load. You are expected to be a mental health clinician without any training or schooling. You have large case loads. You might get a supervisor that has the credentials behind their name but has been out of the SUD field for many years. You might get a micro manager supervisor. You are expected to do billing for both mental health and SUD. They are understaffed and you might be expected to take over someone’s case load and responsibilities if they leave the company without any extra compensation.

job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Seattle, WA
pros: Good hearted co-workers, meaningful work. If you have a lot of wherewithal, you can make a difference in many people's lives.
cons:
The incentive structures come from getting paid for billable hours. This has good intentions, but includes incentives that keep clients around forever (not getting better). This is not the companies fault. 

The company does not really have cohesion and this has created an isolated and passive culture. Everyone leaves everyone else alone, so you can do your own thing, just don't expect there to be support from upper management.

review_title: Ho-Hum and Typical Community Mental Health Care agency
pros:
- Close to home.
- bus access for clients 
- clean (TukE building at least)
cons:
- lowest pay for community mental health care in king county 
- when you get another degree....they give you a 25 cent raise ( no joke) 
- good luck finding parking 
- lack of communication between departments so I have no idea what half the people at the company do 
- management keeps adding more responsibilities and a more and more cases to your caseload .
- technology that breaks constantly or is unreliable 
- leaky building that floods
- all they care about is making sure you get enough direct client hours

job_title: Facilities Maintenance Tech in Seattle, WA
pros: There are some really genuinely great folks who work at SMH and are dedicated to improving the lives through social work with folks with mental illness. Generally speaking the people are will to discuss problems and work collaboratively and my management, in Facilities management, was willing to train and develop my skills to fit their operations.
cons: The pay wasn't going to be what is needed to be and that seemed to be a common trend. There was annual reviews but seldom raises. In fighting was also a huge problem and frequently folks through each other under the bus or tried to micro manage other departments.

review_title: If I knew what I was getting myself into....
job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Seattle, WA
pros: Great location, 3 weeks/ year vacation
cons: LOW PAY - when I started, I was offered the same starting pay as Trader Joe's!!!! My particular coordinator plays favorites & acts as if you're only as good as the last great thing you did which is really disenhearting. Coordinators and above are clique-y. HR is not supportive of the employees. Health care benefits suck - I can't afford to get a second medication that I believe I could benefit from.

pros: CEO is awesome and forward thinking
cons:
New COO is taking us backwards. He is pushing people that are doing an awesome job away from the company. In the short time he has been there, he is showing that the old guard is coming back and its frustrating. People have been employed a long time doing good things, he is questioning there ability for no reason at all. It reminds you of entitled management thinking from back in the 80s. Upper management doesn't know or is oblivious to the danger this is causing for the future of the agency. Please don't reinvent the  wheel. We have lost good people since he has arrived. You can tell that he comes from the "Good ole boy" network. And this is 2019. I thought that network was done away with but NO!! he smoothed his way in. It's just a matter of time that things will hit the fan. He will methodically get rid of people that doesnt (FIT) in his old thinking ways. This process is a cancer that eats away your staff until the only remaining experienced staff you have are beyond disgruntled. These people are so bitter that they spend most trying to screw over each other in order to make themselves feel better. 
The "good ol' boys club" mentality pretty much turns our place of work into high school. The popular kids do what they want and push people around, all because they have nothing to fear disciplinary wise. The Good Ole Boys Club: An Antiquated System That No Longer Belongs In America. The Good ole boys club is a club where men like Roy Moore are protected and get away with despicable behavior. This club has been in America for centuries, it was created during an era where only men who look like them had sole authority and was the only governing force in our nation. Sound you have been warned. I admire the CEO and CFO but they need to look

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Tukwila, WA
pros: Nice therapist who are welcoming and eager to help their clients.
cons: The company presents as a well ran agency with the goal of helping people in need e.g. clients and being supportive to their therapist. Poor, inexperienced and inaccessible supervisors to give new staff and new licensed therapist no supervision. For all clinicians applying think of “smoke and mirrors” to bring you on.  Nepotism at its best to advance staff to positions that in no way they were qualified to do.  Personally witnessing being disrespectful to clients by minimizing their concerns. Poor poor leadership. Do not consider applying there and do your research for whatever you apply for!

job_title: Clinical Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: Humanitarian paradise, opportunities to help your fellow humans. Wonderful psychiatrists. Fantastic program for developmentally disabled adults. David O'Neal is the best manager in the world.
cons: So much humanity to care for, not enough people, but that is down to government grants and budgets. Good health care for you, not reduced much for addition family.

pros: Flexible schedules and decent benefits. It'd be nice if they covered spouses. My partner is not covered and I don't have kids but someone with five children gets to cover every child.
cons: Masters level employees are not compensated for the sheer fact of having a masters.

pros: Excellent clinical colleagues, for the most part.  Good benefits.  Interesting work.
cons: Little or no support from upper management who often acted in an unprofessional manner.  Low pay.  Caseloads are too big to provide good service.

review_title: Inconsistency of care for our clients
pros:
Most of my colleagues are great.
Clients are inspirational.
Great foot in door experience.
cons:
Inconsistency for both employees and clients alike.
Supervisors inform you to do one thing a certain way one day and then do it the complete opposite the next day.

job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Seattle, WA
pros: My supervisor was amazing - understanding, approachable, and went to bat for me. Benefit package was good. Location was good for me.
cons: Workload was nearly impossible. High volume caseloads and many no-shows left me feeling underutilized, but still responsible for all the paperwork.

job_title: Clinical Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: The company is actively trying to improve retention rates and are strong advocate for mental health in the King County region.
cons: The salary does not take into account how expensive the cost of education and living are for young graduates. Student loan forgiveness is not a program to encourage.

job_title: Mental Health Counselor in Seattle, WA
pros: Flexible and accommodating to personal needs and generally supportive supervisors.
cons: High turnover rate because of low pay, minimal raises and several pay deductions from our health benefits to raises of insurance premiums.

pros: When I started here, I learned great skills from the managers I had then.
cons: If you liked the military, you will love Sound Mental Health.  With few exceptions, the current managers are unskilled with both clients and supervision, and over 50 people left during the time I worked there.

review_title: Used to be great but management doesn’t listen
job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Bellevue, WA
pros:
Flexibility for scheduling 
Benefits 
Standing desk
No shortage of direct service hours for licensing
cons:
Impossibly high caseloads
Inconsistent supervision, sometimes no supervision 
Management is disengaged, shows up to work when they want and leaves when they want
Feedback from staff is not acted on

pros: If you like working with community mental health clients, it's pretty decent
cons: Too corporate, pay stinks and client bad behavior is expected.  If you are not prepared to protect yourself, you are not safe working in a place like this.

pros: Great place to work and learn about therapeutic foster care.
cons: This particular position was not a "counseling" position. More case management.

review_title: Not a bad place to be a manager
pros: Healthy organization likely to thrive in a Seattle market where many mental health non profits probably will not
cons: Large, can be slow-moving to change

review_title: I loved working for Sound Mental Health
job_title: CERTIFIED PEER SPECIALIST in Tukwila, WA
pros: They care about there employees. When I had a problem. It got took care of real fast. Great place to work
cons: Getting to close to the consumers

pros: Great company, great benefits, does great work for their consumers.
cons: low pay, very high caseloads

job_title: Accounts Receivable Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: SMH believes in it's mission statement and will do anything to achieve it.
cons: forgets about it's employee on its way to achieving it's goals.

pros: Work with a great team, lots of freedom
cons: not enough money, supervision or hours in the week to get the job done

pros:
-Understanding and supportive supervisors
-Great benefits
-Awesome IT support
cons:
-High caseload
-Not enough interactions between programs

pros: front line work, it pays to be a independent worker because the caseloads are too high. loved the clients and staff!
cons: SMH is growing to big and cannot manage its growth. staff are not treated like professionals and managers are not qualified or able to manage.

pros: Attentive supervisors, flexible, good work-life balance. I worked for SSVF (Supportive Services for Veteran Families), under parent company Sound.
cons: Pay could have been better

pros: Opportunity to be hired on after internship; many locations to choose from.
cons: Many challenges are faced at community mental health agencies in general.

job_title: Residential Case Manager in Seattle, WA
pros: This is a great way to work in the field with minimal education
cons: Work is difficult; lots of responsibilities

review_title: A good place for new counselors
pros: Management and supervisors are super supportive
cons: The caseloads can get pretty high

pros: supervisors and co workers were great
cons: client to staff ratio imbalance

review_title: Discouraged due to low wages and large case loads.
job_title: Mental Health Clinician in Seattle, WA
pros: The staff is excellent. Supervision is also really good.
cons: Population is hard to work with. Caseloads are extremely heavy. The pay is below average.
